segment.source: description: This case study, which builds on the info given in Bookstore, begins with a Windows Phone Silverlight app that displays grouped data in a LongListSelector.
segment.target: description: This case study, which builds on the info given in Bookstore, begins with a Windows Phone Silverlight app that displays grouped data in a LongListSelector.

segment.source: title: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore2
segment.target: title: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore2

segment.source: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore2
segment.target: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP case study: Bookstore2

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This case study—which builds on the info given in Bookstore1—begins with a Windows Phone Silverlight app that displays grouped data in a LongListSelector.
segment.target: This case study—which builds on the info given in Bookstore1—begins with a Windows Phone Silverlight app that displays grouped data in a LongListSelector.

segment.source: In the view model, each instance of the class Author represents the group of the books written by that author, and in the LongListSelector, we can either view the list of books grouped by author or we can zoom out to see a jump list of authors.
segment.target: In the view model, each instance of the class Author represents the group of the books written by that author, and in the LongListSelector, we can either view the list of books grouped by author or we can zoom out to see a jump list of authors.

segment.source: The jump list affords much quicker navigation than scrolling through the list of books.
segment.target: The jump list affords much quicker navigation than scrolling through the list of books.

segment.source: We walk through the steps of porting the app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: We walk through the steps of porting the app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Note When opening Bookstore2Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.
segment.target: Note When opening Bookstore2Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.

segment.source: Downloads
segment.target: Downloads

segment.source: Download the Bookstore2WPSL8 Windows Phone Silverlight app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore2WPSL8 Windows Phone Silverlight app.

segment.source: Download the Bookstore2Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore2Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.

segment.source: The Windows Phone Silverlight app
segment.target: The Windows Phone Silverlight app

segment.source: The illustration below shows what Bookstore2WPSL8—the app that we're going to port—looks like.
segment.target: The illustration below shows what Bookstore2WPSL8—the app that we're going to port—looks like.

segment.source: It's a vertically-scrolling LongListSelector of books grouped by author.
segment.target: It's a vertically-scrolling LongListSelector of books grouped by author.

segment.source: You can zoom out to the jump list, and from there, you can navigate back into any group.
segment.target: You can zoom out to the jump list, and from there, you can navigate back into any group.

segment.source: There are two main pieces to this app: the view model that provides the grouped data source, and the user interface that binds to that view model.
segment.target: There are two main pieces to this app: the view model that provides the grouped data source, and the user interface that binds to that view model.

segment.source: As we'll see, both of these pieces port easily from Windows Phone Silverlight technology to the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: As we'll see, both of these pieces port easily from Windows Phone Silverlight technology to the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: how bookstore2wpsl8 looks
segment.target: how bookstore2wpsl8 looks

segment.source: Porting to a Windows 10 project
segment.target: Porting to a Windows 10 project

segment.source: It's a quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore2WPSL8, and include the copied files in the new project.
segment.target: It's a quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore2WPSL8, and include the copied files in the new project.

segment.source: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.
segment.target: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.

segment.source: Name it Bookstore2Universal\_10.
segment.target: Name it Bookstore2Universal\_10.

segment.source: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore2WPSL8 to Bookstore2Universal\_10.
segment.target: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore2WPSL8 to Bookstore2Universal\_10.

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).

segment.source: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.
segment.target: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.

segment.source: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.
segment.target: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.

segment.source: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.
segment.target: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.

segment.source: Each time you copy a file or folder, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.
segment.target: Each time you copy a file or folder, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.

segment.source: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.
segment.target: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).

segment.source: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.
segment.target: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.

segment.source: We can keep the App.xaml, and App.xaml.cs that Visual Studio generated for us in the Windows 10 project.
segment.target: We can keep the App.xaml, and App.xaml.cs that Visual Studio generated for us in the Windows 10 project.

segment.source: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore2WPSL8 namespace to Bookstore2Universal\_10.
segment.target: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore2WPSL8 namespace to Bookstore2Universal\_10.

segment.source: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.
segment.target: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.

segment.source: In the imperative code in the view model source file, these porting changes are needed.
segment.target: In the imperative code in the view model source file, these porting changes are needed.

segment.source: Change to and then use the Resolve command on it.
segment.target: Change to and then use the Resolve command on it.

segment.source: Delete the property and use IntelliSense to add the correct property name: .
segment.target: Delete the property and use IntelliSense to add the correct property name: .

segment.target: Use the Resolve command on .

segment.target: Use the Resolve command on .

segment.target: Delete and .

segment.target: Change the value returned by the Bookstore2Universal\_10.BookstoreViewModel.AppName property from "BOOKSTORE2WPSL8" to "BOOKSTORE2UNIVERSAL".

segment.source: Just as we did for Bookstore1, update the implementation of the BookSku.CoverImage property (see Binding an Image to a view model).
segment.target: Just as we did for Bookstore1, update the implementation of the BookSku.CoverImage property (see Binding an Image to a view model).

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml, these initial porting changes are needed.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml, these initial porting changes are needed.

segment.source: Change to (including the occurrences in property element syntax).
segment.target: Change to (including the occurrences in property element syntax).

segment.source: Delete the and namespace prefix declarations.
segment.target: Delete the and namespace prefix declarations.

segment.source: Change "clr-namespace" to "using" in the remaining namespace prefix declaration.
segment.target: Change "clr-namespace" to "using" in the remaining namespace prefix declaration.

segment.source: Delete , and , and configure Portrait in the app package manifest in the new project.
segment.target: Delete , and , and configure Portrait in the app package manifest in the new project.

segment.target: Delete .

segment.source: The types of the jump list item converters (which are present in the markup as resources) have moved to the Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives namespace.
segment.target: The types of the jump list item converters (which are present in the markup as resources) have moved to the Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives namespace.

segment.source: So, add the namespace prefix declaration Windows\_UI\_Xaml\_Controls\_Primitives and map it to Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.
segment.target: So, add the namespace prefix declaration Windows\_UI\_Xaml\_Controls\_Primitives and map it to Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Primitives.

segment.source: On the jump list item converter resources, change the prefix from to .
segment.target: On the jump list item converter resources, change the prefix from to .

segment.source: Just as we did for Bookstore1, replace all references to the TextBlock style with a reference to , replace with , replace with , and replace with .
segment.target: Just as we did for Bookstore1, replace all references to the TextBlock style with a reference to , replace with , replace with , and replace with .

segment.source: There is one exception in .
segment.target: There is one exception in .

segment.target: The style of the second TextBlock should reference .

segment.source: Remove the FontFamily attribute from the TextBlock inside and set the Background of the Border to reference instead of .
segment.target: Remove the FontFamily attribute from the TextBlock inside and set the Background of the Border to reference instead of .

segment.source: Because of changes related to view pixels, go through the markup and multiply any fixed size dimension (margins, width, height, etc) by 0.8.
segment.target: Because of changes related to view pixels, go through the markup and multiply any fixed size dimension (margins, width, height, etc) by 0.8.

segment.source: Replacing the LongListSelector
segment.target: Replacing the LongListSelector

segment.source: Replacing the LongListSelector with a SemanticZoom control will take several steps, so let's make a start on that.
segment.target: Replacing the LongListSelector with a SemanticZoom control will take several steps, so let's make a start on that.

segment.source: A LongListSelector binds directly to the grouped data source, but a SemanticZoom contains ListView or GridView controls, which bind indirectly to the data via a CollectionViewSource adapter.
segment.target: A LongListSelector binds directly to the grouped data source, but a SemanticZoom contains ListView or GridView controls, which bind indirectly to the data via a CollectionViewSource adapter.

segment.source: The CollectionViewSource needs to be present in the markup as a resource, so let's begin by adding that to the markup in MainPage.xaml inside .
segment.target: The CollectionViewSource needs to be present in the markup as a resource, so let's begin by adding that to the markup in MainPage.xaml inside .

segment.source: Note that the binding on LongListSelector.ItemsSource becomes the value of CollectionViewSource.Source, and LongListSelector.IsGroupingEnabled becomes CollectionViewSource.IsSourceGrouped.
segment.target: Note that the binding on LongListSelector.ItemsSource becomes the value of CollectionViewSource.Source, and LongListSelector.IsGroupingEnabled becomes CollectionViewSource.IsSourceGrouped.

segment.source: The CollectionViewSource has a name (note: not a key, as you might expect) so that we can bind to it.
segment.target: The CollectionViewSource has a name (note: not a key, as you might expect) so that we can bind to it.

segment.source: Next, replace the with this markup, which will give us a preliminary SemanticZoom to work with.
segment.target: Next, replace the with this markup, which will give us a preliminary SemanticZoom to work with.

segment.source: The LongListSelector notion of flat list and jump list modes is answered in the SemanticZoom notion of a zoomed-in and a zoomed-out view, respectively.
segment.target: The LongListSelector notion of flat list and jump list modes is answered in the SemanticZoom notion of a zoomed-in and a zoomed-out view, respectively.

segment.source: The zoomed-in view is a property, and you set that property to an instance of a ListView.
segment.target: The zoomed-in view is a property, and you set that property to an instance of a ListView.

segment.source: In this case, the zoomed-out view is also set to a ListView, and both ListView controls are bound to our CollectionViewSource.
segment.target: In this case, the zoomed-out view is also set to a ListView, and both ListView controls are bound to our CollectionViewSource.

segment.source: The zoomed-in view uses the same item template, group header template, and HideEmptyGroups setting (now named HidesIfEmpty) as the LongListSelector's flat list does.
segment.target: The zoomed-in view uses the same item template, group header template, and HideEmptyGroups setting (now named HidesIfEmpty) as the LongListSelector's flat list does.

segment.source: And the zoomed-out view uses an item template very much like the one inside the LongListSelector's jump list style ().
segment.target: And the zoomed-out view uses an item template very much like the one inside the LongListSelector's jump list style ().

segment.source: Also, note that the zoomed-out view binds to a special property of the CollectionViewSource named CollectionGroups, which is a collection containing the groups rather than the items.
segment.target: Also, note that the zoomed-out view binds to a special property of the CollectionViewSource named CollectionGroups, which is a collection containing the groups rather than the items.

segment.source: We no longer need , at least not all of it.
segment.target: We no longer need , at least not all of it.

segment.source: We only need the data template for the groups (which are authors in this app) in the zoomed-out view.
segment.target: We only need the data template for the groups (which are authors in this app) in the zoomed-out view.

segment.source: So, we delete the style and replace it with this data template.
segment.target: So, we delete the style and replace it with this data template.

segment.source: Note that, since the data context of this data template is a group rather than an item, we bind to a special property named Group.
segment.target: Note that, since the data context of this data template is a group rather than an item, we bind to a special property named Group.

segment.source: You can build and run the app now.
segment.target: You can build and run the app now.

segment.source: Here's how it looks on the mobile emulator.
segment.target: Here's how it looks on the mobile emulator.

segment.source: the uwp app on mobile with initial source code changes
segment.target: the uwp app on mobile with initial source code changes

segment.source: The view model and the zoomed-in and zoomed-out views are working together correctly, although one issue is that we need to do a little more styling and templating work.
segment.target: The view model and the zoomed-in and zoomed-out views are working together correctly, although one issue is that we need to do a little more styling and templating work.

segment.source: For example, the correct styles and brushes are not yet being used, so the text is invisible on the group headers that you can click to zoom out.
segment.target: For example, the correct styles and brushes are not yet being used, so the text is invisible on the group headers that you can click to zoom out.

segment.source: If you run the app on a desktop device, then you'll see a second issue, which is that the app doesn't yet adapt its user-interface to give the best experience and use of space on larger devices where windows can be potentially much larger than the screen of a mobile device.
segment.target: If you run the app on a desktop device, then you'll see a second issue, which is that the app doesn't yet adapt its user-interface to give the best experience and use of space on larger devices where windows can be potentially much larger than the screen of a mobile device.

segment.source: So, in the next few sections (Initial styling and templating, Adaptive UI, and Final styling), we'll remedy those issues.
segment.target: So, in the next few sections (Initial styling and templating, Adaptive UI, and Final styling), we'll remedy those issues.

segment.source: Initial styling and templating
segment.target: Initial styling and templating

segment.source: To space out the group headers nicely, edit and set a Margin of on the Border.
segment.target: To space out the group headers nicely, edit and set a Margin of on the Border.

segment.source: To space out the book items nicely, Edit and set the Margin to on both TextBlocks.
segment.target: To space out the book items nicely, Edit and set the Margin to on both TextBlocks.

segment.source: To lay out the app name and the page title a little better, inside , remove the top Margin on the second TextBlock by setting the value to .
segment.target: To lay out the app name and the page title a little better, inside , remove the top Margin on the second TextBlock by setting the value to .

segment.source: And on itself, set the margin to (or whatever value looks good to you)
segment.target: And on itself, set the margin to (or whatever value looks good to you)

segment.source: Change 's Background to .
segment.target: Change 's Background to .

segment.source: Adaptive UI
segment.target: Adaptive UI

segment.source: Because we started out with a phone app, it's no surprise that our ported app's UI layout really only makes sense for small devices and narrow windows at this stage in the process.
segment.target: Because we started out with a phone app, it's no surprise that our ported app's UI layout really only makes sense for small devices and narrow windows at this stage in the process.

segment.source: But, we'd really like the UI layout to adapt itself and make better use of space when the app is running in a wide window (which is only possible on a device with a large screen), and for it only to use the UI that we have currently when the app's window is narrow (which happens on a small device, and can also happen on a large device).
segment.target: But, we'd really like the UI layout to adapt itself and make better use of space when the app is running in a wide window (which is only possible on a device with a large screen), and for it only to use the UI that we have currently when the app's window is narrow (which happens on a small device, and can also happen on a large device).

segment.source: We can use the adaptive Visual State Manager feature to achieve this.
segment.target: We can use the adaptive Visual State Manager feature to achieve this.

segment.source: We'll set properties on visual elements so that, by default, the UI is laid out in the narrow state using the templates that we're using right now.
segment.target: We'll set properties on visual elements so that, by default, the UI is laid out in the narrow state using the templates that we're using right now.

segment.source: Then, we'll detect when the app's window is wider-than-or-equal-to a specific size (measured in units of effective pixels), and in response, we'll change the properties of visual elements so that we get a larger, and wider, layout.
segment.target: Then, we'll detect when the app's window is wider-than-or-equal-to a specific size (measured in units of effective pixels), and in response, we'll change the properties of visual elements so that we get a larger, and wider, layout.

segment.source: We'll put those property changes in a visual state, and we'll use an adaptive trigger to continuously monitor and determine whether to apply that visual state, or not, depending on the width of the window in effective pixels.
segment.target: We'll put those property changes in a visual state, and we'll use an adaptive trigger to continuously monitor and determine whether to apply that visual state, or not, depending on the width of the window in effective pixels.

segment.source: We're triggering on window width in this case, but it's possible to trigger on window height, too.
segment.target: We're triggering on window width in this case, but it's possible to trigger on window height, too.

segment.source: A minimum window width of 548 epx is appropriate for this use case because that's the size of the smallest device we would want to show the wide layout on.
segment.target: A minimum window width of 548 epx is appropriate for this use case because that's the size of the smallest device we would want to show the wide layout on.

segment.source: Phones are typically smaller than 548 epx, so on a small device like that, we'd remain in the default narrow layout.
segment.target: Phones are typically smaller than 548 epx, so on a small device like that, we'd remain in the default narrow layout.

segment.source: On a PC, the window will launch by default wide enough to trigger the switch to the wide state, which will display 250x250-sized items.
segment.target: On a PC, the window will launch by default wide enough to trigger the switch to the wide state, which will display 250x250-sized items.

segment.source: From there, you'll be able to drag the window narrow enough to display a minimum of two columns of the 250x250 items.
segment.target: From there, you'll be able to drag the window narrow enough to display a minimum of two columns of the 250x250 items.

segment.source: Any narrower than that and the trigger will deactivate, the wide visual state will be removed, and the default narrow layout will be in effect.
segment.target: Any narrower than that and the trigger will deactivate, the wide visual state will be removed, and the default narrow layout will be in effect.

segment.source: Before tackling the adaptive Visual State Manager piece, we first need to design the wide state and that means adding some new visual elements and templates to our markup.
segment.target: Before tackling the adaptive Visual State Manager piece, we first need to design the wide state and that means adding some new visual elements and templates to our markup.

segment.source: These steps describe how to do that.
segment.target: These steps describe how to do that.

segment.source: By way of naming conventions for visual elements and templates, we'll include the word "wide" in the name of any element or template that is for the wide state.
segment.target: By way of naming conventions for visual elements and templates, we'll include the word "wide" in the name of any element or template that is for the wide state.

segment.source: If an element or template does not contain the word "wide", then you can assume that it is for the narrow state, which is the default state and whose property values are set as local values on visual elements in the page.
segment.target: If an element or template does not contain the word "wide", then you can assume that it is for the narrow state, which is the default state and whose property values are set as local values on visual elements in the page.

segment.source: Only the property values for the wide state are set via an actual Visual State in the markup.
segment.target: Only the property values for the wide state are set via an actual Visual State in the markup.

segment.source: Make a copy of the SemanticZoom control in the markup and set on the copy.
segment.target: Make a copy of the SemanticZoom control in the markup and set on the copy.

segment.source: On the original, set and also set so that the wide one is not visible by default.
segment.target: On the original, set and also set so that the wide one is not visible by default.

segment.target: In , change the ListViews to GridViews in both the zoomed-in view and the zoomed-out view.

segment.target: Make a copy of these three resources , , and and append the word to the keys of the copies.

segment.target: Also, update so that it references the keys of these new resources.

segment.source: Making the view model more flexible
segment.target: Making the view model more flexible

segment.source: This section contains an example of facilities that open up to us by virtue of having moved our app to use the UWP.
segment.target: This section contains an example of facilities that open up to us by virtue of having moved our app to use the UWP.

segment.source: Here, we explain optional steps that you can follow to make your view model more flexible when accessed via a CollectionViewSource.
segment.target: Here, we explain optional steps that you can follow to make your view model more flexible when accessed via a CollectionViewSource.

segment.source: The view model (the source file is in ViewModel\\BookstoreViewModel.cs) that we ported from the Windows Phone Silverlight app Bookstore2WPSL8 contains a class named Author, which derives from List<T>, where T is BookSku.
segment.target: The view model (the source file is in ViewModel\\BookstoreViewModel.cs) that we ported from the Windows Phone Silverlight app Bookstore2WPSL8 contains a class named Author, which derives from List<T>, where T is BookSku.

segment.source: That means that the Author class is a group of BookSku.
segment.target: That means that the Author class is a group of BookSku.

segment.source: When we bind CollectionViewSource.Source to Authors, the only thing we're communicating is that each Author in Authors is a group of something.
segment.target: When we bind CollectionViewSource.Source to Authors, the only thing we're communicating is that each Author in Authors is a group of something.

segment.source: We leave it to the CollectionViewSource to determine that Author is, in this case, a group of BookSku.
segment.target: We leave it to the CollectionViewSource to determine that Author is, in this case, a group of BookSku.

segment.source: That works: but it's not flexible.
segment.target: That works: but it's not flexible.

segment.source: What if we want Author to be both a group of BookSku and a group of the addresses where the author has lived?
segment.target: What if we want Author to be both a group of BookSku and a group of the addresses where the author has lived?

segment.source: Author can't be both of those groups.
segment.target: Author can't be both of those groups.

segment.source: But, Author can have any number of groups.
segment.target: But, Author can have any number of groups.

segment.source: And that's the solution: use the has-a-group pattern instead of, or in addition to, the is-a-group pattern that we're using currently.
segment.target: And that's the solution: use the has-a-group pattern instead of, or in addition to, the is-a-group pattern that we're using currently.

segment.source: Here's how:
segment.target: Here's how:

segment.source: Change Author so that it no longer derives from List<T>.
segment.target: Change Author so that it no longer derives from List<T>.

segment.source: Add this field to Author: .
segment.target: Add this field to Author: .

segment.source: And of course we can repeat the above two steps to add as many groups to Author as we need.
segment.target: And of course we can repeat the above two steps to add as many groups to Author as we need.

segment.source: Now that Author has at least one group, we need to communicate to the CollectionViewSource which of those groups it should use.
segment.target: Now that Author has at least one group, we need to communicate to the CollectionViewSource which of those groups it should use.

segment.source: To do that, add this property to the CollectionViewSource:
segment.target: To do that, add this property to the CollectionViewSource:

segment.source: Those changes leave this app functionally unchanged, but you now know how you could extend Author, and the CollectionViewSource, should you need to.
segment.target: Those changes leave this app functionally unchanged, but you now know how you could extend Author, and the CollectionViewSource, should you need to.

segment.source: Let's make one last change to Author so that, if we use it without specifying CollectionViewSource.ItemsPath, a default group of our choosing will be used:
segment.target: Let's make one last change to Author so that, if we use it without specifying CollectionViewSource.ItemsPath, a default group of our choosing will be used:

segment.source: And now we can choose to remove if we like and the app will still behave the same way.
segment.target: And now we can choose to remove if we like and the app will still behave the same way.

segment.source: Conclusion
segment.target: Conclusion

segment.source: This case study involved a more ambitious user interface than the previous one.
segment.target: This case study involved a more ambitious user interface than the previous one.

segment.source: All of the facilities and concepts of the Windows Phone SilverlightLongListSelector—and more—were found to be available to a UWP app in the form of SemanticZoom, ListView, GridView, and CollectionViewSource.
segment.target: All of the facilities and concepts of the Windows Phone SilverlightLongListSelector—and more—were found to be available to a UWP app in the form of SemanticZoom, ListView, GridView, and CollectionViewSource.

segment.source: We showed how to re-use, or copy-and-edit, both imperative code and markup in a UWP app to achieve functionality, UI, and interactions tailored to suit the narrowest and widest Windows device form factors and all sizes in-between.
segment.target: We showed how to re-use, or copy-and-edit, both imperative code and markup in a UWP app to achieve functionality, UI, and interactions tailored to suit the narrowest and widest Windows device form factors and all sizes in-between.
